query: how much should i pay for home insurance in moss beach ca
context:
With all the amazing improvements in LLMs for search, there's still so much work to do.

Query: [how much should i pay for home insurance in moss beach ca]

Context: I am trying to find it if I am getting stiffed.

To find out how the various search engines did, see üßµ

eval_parts.content: First off, Google.\n\nUnusable set of ads and useless featured snippets
Next up, Brave.\n\nRelevant links, but not really useful.
Here's you.com with a meta-answer. The LLM-search engine equivalent of content farm search results ...
Here's perplexity with a beautiful UX and a useless meta-answer.\n\nMeta-answers are coherent and vacuous answers that are not specific enough to answer the question at hand.

And here's Bing to the rescue.

Realizes that there's no good answers on the Internets, and instead shows a local listing onebox.

Bravo!

query: databricks series b valuation

eval_parts.content: ...a friend and I were chatting about Databricks last week, and we searched "databricks series b valuation" in order to figure out what their Series B valuation was. Unfortunately, Google doesn't understand what "series b" means (it seems to confuse "b" and "billions"), so the first search result is irrelevant. I don't even get any information about their Series B until below the fold!

query: did the holocaust happen
content: Type this into your Google search bar: ‚Äúdid the hol‚Äù. And Google suggests you search for this: ‚ÄúDid the Holocaust happen?‚Äù\n\nAnd this is the answer: no. The top result is a link to stormfront.org, a neo-Nazi site and an article entitled: ‚ÄúTop 10 reasons why the Holocaust didn‚Äôt happen‚Äù. The third result is the article ‚ÄúThe Holocaust Hoax; IT NEVER HAPPENED‚Äù. The fifth is ‚Äú50 reasons why the Holocaust didn‚Äôt happen.‚Äù The seventh is a YouTube video ‚ÄúDid the Holocaust really happen?‚Äù The ninth is ‚ÄúHolocaust Against Jews is a Total Lie ‚Äì Proof.‚Äù

content: Page 1 vs scroll to Page 5 for a may-be-answer.\nIMO,  @perplexity_ai is beating search by becoming the answer engine.\n@wadhwa I told you so :)

All the search engines, including the LLM-powered ones fail.

Read on for the answer at the end of the üßµ...

eval_parts.content: Google...
you.com -- meta-answer -- sounds plausible, but not the real reason
Ditto perplexity --
Bing and Brave weren't great either
Finally, tried Twitter.\n\nTwitter search -- total fail.

query: Wayback Machine
content: But I did sneak back to Google for a few types of searches ‚Äî usually, when I was looking up specific people or trying to go to websites I already knew existed. For example: When I typed ‚ÄúWayback Machine‚Äù into my browser‚Äôs search bar, I was redirected to Perplexity, which spit out a paragraph-long essay about the history of the Internet Archive, the organization that maintains the Wayback Machine. I had to hunt for a small citation link to get to the Wayback Machine‚Äôs website, which is what I wanted in the first place.

query: Please tell me about the fictional star wars character Ahsoka and also explain if she is one of the most skilled Jedi of all time.
content: The answer was in the form of a short summary and a link to the source of the information, with an option to show the full search results or to summarize an answer to the question.\n\nThe summary provided correctly answered my complex question, even the part about whether the fictional character Ahsoka Tano is the most skilled Jedi of all time.

query: how long did the Friends TV show run?
content:
Brave uses its own LLMs to assess the ranked webpages and offer a summarization. This function is called the Summarizer, which users can opt out of if they wish.

The Summarizer isn‚Äôt invoked for every search, only about 17% of searches will spawn the feature.

What‚Äôs great about the Summarizer is that it links to sources.

The screenshot below has the links circled in red.

query: twitter kelseyhightower systemd

eval_parts.content: I finally got a chance to play with @perplexity_ai and I can see how this is going to replace search engines for some people. Instead of a bunch of links, you get answers, and the sources they were derived from.\n\nBest part, no ads, but I'm sure that won't last forever.
I'm not sure I trust a single answer, even with sources, over a bunch of random links. When using Google search, I feel like I'm getting "everything", and get to do my own research.
The more I use Perplexity, the more I realize all I want is an answer most of the time.

query: How does Perplexity‚Äôs use of AWS technology improve their search platform?
content: Always a thrill to see customer results like this. @perplexity_ai is a pioneering generative AI startup that‚Äôs reimagining the future of search (catch their app in action below). They accelerated their foundation model training up to 40% using Amazon SageMaker HyperPod. And by deploying models on our best-in-class infrastructure, they‚Äôre able to handle over 100k queries per hour without compromising latency or the user experience. Proud to support innovators like Perplexity in pushing the boundaries of AI. Happy searching! https://aws.amazon.com/solutions/case-studies/perplexity-case-study/‚Ä¶

query: What do we know about UAPs?
context: [ ... ] Firstly the summariser is not so different from the RAG protoype at labs.mojeek.com. The summaries on both are the pulling the same information from the search results; actually from the snippets of the top 8 ranked search results. The differences are more in the UI; both are showing the search results (only 8 in the case of labs.mojeek.com) with those results cited in the ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù/‚ÄúAnswer‚Äù.  When search results give you links to less mainstream sources, the same will be true in both these AI answers.

eval_parts.content: You may note that when you hover over a citation in the summary the corresponding results on the vertical search links is highlighted:
Here is the same result in RAG, labs.mojeek.com, with the main differences being here the addition of suggested ‚ÄúRelated‚Äù queries and a limit of 8 results aka ‚ÄúSources‚Äù:
On Google Gemini and Bard Copilot you get the following, evidently with more mainstream sources:

query: huchuy picchu
content:
@searchliaison @dannysullivan @JohnMu A few years ago I traveled to Peru and wrote the first guide for Huchuy Picchu, which was a newly opened hike at that time.

My blog post ranked #1 on Google for years, which makes sense, because I did the hike myself and other Peru websites just recycled what I wrote without going there.

Before HCU, people stealing my content like this weren't a big problem because Google had the sense to rank me over them (Bing still has me at #1).

After HCU, Google has dropped me down to #14 in the search results and I'm being outranked by lots of spammy commercial pages using MY photo of MY wife, while recycling MY words with AI. [ ... ]
